subject: The Morning: Freezing the government
body:
Plus, R.F.K. Jr., war in Congo and the Lunar New Year.
View in browser
|
nytimes.com
January 29, 2025
By 
German Lopez
Good morning. We’re covering how President Trump is trying to reshape the government — as well as R.F.K. Jr., war in Congo and the Lunar New Year.
President Trump 
Kenny Holston/The New York Times
Freezing the government
President Trump believes that a deep state held him back in his first term. Now, he wants to go through the federal government and its many functions, line by line, to make sure he gets his way — on diversity, climate change, immigration and more.
Yesterday, the Trump administration tried to freeze a host of federal grants and loans while it figures out whether these priorities align with the president’s agenda. The directive subjects programs to “ideological litmus tests,” my colleague Nicholas Nehamas 
wrote
. It says government money should not “advance Marxist equity, transgenderism and Green New Deal social engineering.” Moments before it was set to begin, 
a judge suspended the freeze
; a ruling will follow next week.
The president is trying to strip any policy or program that he and his allies might call “woke.” He has already moved to bar transgender people from the military and to prevent the government from paying for transgender children’s treatments. He revoked a 60-year-old order that bans hiring discrimination in federal contracting and ended D.E.I. programs for the federal work force.
Lawmakers often say that “personnel is policy.” Trump is taking that view seriously as a way to ensure that his new policies are actually enforced, after some federal employees 
admitted that they secretly undermined
 his first-term agenda.
So the president ordered federal employees to report on colleagues who try to continue D.E.I. efforts. He has dismissed officials who he believes oppose him. Yesterday, his administration offered millions of federal employees 
payouts to resign
. It promised to impose “enhanced standards of conduct” to judge if workers are “reliable, loyal, trustworthy.”
The funding freeze is also part of an effort to enforce Trump’s agenda across the entire government. By looking at each agency on a granular level, Trump can see if everyone is doing what he wants. The rest of today’s newsletter breaks down what may happen if the freeze goes forward.
‘Temporary pause’
If the freeze proceeds, some programs that Americans rely on will shut down, though the administration called it a “temporary pause.” My colleagues have put together 
a list of potentially affected programs
. They include:
Federal Transit Formula Grants
, which local officials use to operate city buses and trains.
The 
National School Lunch Program
, which feeds poor schoolchildren.
The 
Wildfire Crisis Strategy Landscapes
, which funds projects to prevent wildfires.
The 
CHIPS Incentives Program
, which supports the manufacturing of semiconductors in the U.S.
Special Education Grants to States,
 which help students with disabilities.
The 
High-Intensity Drug Trafficking Areas Program
, which helps the police stop drug crimes.
The administration said it excluded some major services — Social Security, Medicare and food stamps, for instance — from the freeze. “Any payment required by law to be paid will be paid without interruption or delay,” the Office of Management and Budget said.
But the freeze might be illegal. The Constitution gives Congress power of the purse, meaning that its members decide how the government spends its money. The president has some leeway (say, in picking contractors), but he typically can’t decide to withhold money. The Supreme Court has rebuked past efforts by presidents to “impound” funds in this way. In 1975, it ruled against Richard Nixon when he cut off some environmental protection funds.
Mass confusion
A press briefing at the White House. 
Evan Vucci/Associated Press
When the administration issued the directive on Monday, officials across the government wondered if it would affect them. At first, the White House sent agencies a giant spreadsheet of affected programs, asking officials to explain if any violated Trump’s executive orders. Then, the administration rushed to clarify that it exempted some big programs, like Medicaid and Head Start.
But in the pandemonium, states reported yesterday that Medicaid payments were frozen. Providers who care for young children said they couldn’t access Head Start funds. Gov. Jeff Landry of Louisiana, a Trump ally, issued a statement asking the administration to take steps to avoid “jeopardizing the financial stability of the state.”
Trump views unpredictability as a virtue that keeps his opponents guessing. In this case, maybe the cuts related to wokeness or climate change will scare federal employees into acting cautiously — to avoid getting on their boss’s bad side.
But that unpredictability also has another effect: As Trump moves quickly, some government services — and the things they pay for, like schools and policing — might not always function as Americans expect.
More on the funding
Attorneys general from 22 states and Washington, D.C., filed a lawsuit 
challenging Trump’s funding freeze
.
The administration’s relentless stream of orders and directives is 
a deliberate effort to “flood the zone,”
 experts say.
Trump hopes that his blitz on the federal government will send a message, Peter Baker writes: 
Get out of the way or get run over
.
THE LATEST NEWS
Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
Robert F. Kennedy Jr.  
Kenny Holston/The New York Times
Senate hearings begin today for 
Robert F. Kennedy Jr.
, Trump’s pick for health secretary. He would oversee several major agencies, including the C.D.C. and the F.D.A.
Kennedy, a critic of childhood vaccines, would have power over a government program that 
gives free vaccines
 to millions of low-income children.
Kennedy’s suspicion of food and drug companies has won him an unusual group of fans for a former Democrat: 
conservative Christian mothers
.
Caroline Kennedy, a former U.S. ambassador and the daughter of John F. Kennedy, urged senators to 
reject the nomination
. She called her cousin unfit for the job and a “predator.” 
Read her letter
.
Track Trump’s cabinet confirmations here
.
Trump Administration
Trump signed an executive order to 
restrict transgender medical treatments
, including surgery and hormone therapy, for people under 19.
The Senate confirmed 
Sean Duffy
, a former Wisconsin congressman, as secretary of transportation.
Pete Hegseth removed Gen. Mark Milley’s 
security detail and security clearance
 and ordered a review of his record. Milley stood up to Trump in his first term.
The Trump administration 
revoked deportation protections
 that Joe Biden had extended for more than 600,000 Venezuelans in the U.S.
Kash Patel, the president’s pick for F.B.I. director, has long emphasized his personal loyalty to Trump. The agency has made independence 
central to its identity
.
More on Politics
Oklahoma education leaders approved a plan that would require public schools 
to request proof of children’s immigration status
.
Senate Democrats blocked a bill to 
impose sanctions on officials of the International Criminal Court
. The bill, which the House passed, is a rebuke of the court’s decision to charge Israeli leaders with war crimes.
A Senate seat in Michigan will soon be vacant. Pete Buttigieg is among 
the politicians considering a run
.
Trump’s preferred candidates to replace former Representatives Matt Gaetz and Michael Waltz 
easily won their special election primaries
.
International
In Manila, Philippines. 
Eloisa Lopez/Reuters
Today is Lunar New Year. Billions of people celebrated with fireworks and feasts. 
See photos
 from across Asia.
Eight of the 26 hostages
 that Hamas plans to return to Israel in the coming weeks are dead, Israeli officials said.
A Hindu celebration at a holy river in India turned into a stampede. 
Dozens of people may have died
.
Rwanda has cultivated good relations with Western leaders and donors. Those leaders have said little as Rwandan-backed rebels 
wage war in the Democratic Republic of Congo
.
Business
X, formerly Twitter, announced a deal with Visa to let users 
send money through the app
.
Venture capitalists invested billions in start-ups like OpenAI and Anthropic. The rise of the China’s DeepSeek 
calls that funding frenzy into question
.
The cable news anchor Jim Acosta is 
leaving CNN
. The network told him it was moving his show to midnight.
A new CVS app will let some customers 
unlock stores’ glass security cabinets
 without waiting for a clerk.
Other Big Stories
American children’s 
reading skills have continued to decline
, according to federal test scores.
Kansas is dealing with 
a major tuberculosis outbreak
. Dozens of people in the Kansas City, Kan., area have the disease, officials said.
Opinions
Trump’s pause of the TikTok ban could begin an economic era in which 
the government picks winners and losers
 — as China does, 
Tim Wu
 writes.
The Chicago police 
pulled a live coyote
 from a supermarket produce aisle last week. Nature is always closer than we think, 
Margaret Renkl
 writes.
Here’s a column by 
Bret Stephens
 on 
the end of diversity programs
.
The Times Sale: Our best rate for readers of The Morning.
Save now with our best offer on unlimited news and analysis as part of the complete Times experience: 
$1/week for your first year
.
MORNING READS
In Hazard, Ky. 
Jon Cherry for The New York Times
On the mountaintop: 
As flood risks increase, Kentucky is relocating people 
to mine-cratered higher ground
.
Survival: 
The plane crash should have killed her. 
Sometimes she wishes it had
.
Ask Well: 
“Does hot lemon water 
have any health benefits
?”
Lives Lived: 
Pableaux Johnson was a New Orleans food writer, photographer and cook who documented Mardi Gras traditions and served red beans and rice to thousands. He 
died at 59
.
SPORTS
N.B.A.: 
The Kings are open to trading the star guard De’Aaron Fox, 
perhaps to the Spurs
.
W.N.B.A.:
 The Phoenix Mercury will 
acquire Alyssa Thomas
, a five-time All-Star, from the Connecticut Sun. And Brittney Griner agreed to a 
one-year deal with the Atlanta Dream
 after 11 seasons with the Mercury.
ARTS AND IDEAS
Linda Xiao for The New York Times
It’s Dumpling Week, an NYT Cooking celebration of Lunar New Year featuring five new recipes for your dumpling party. “All the good feelings rush in with dumplings,” Genevieve Ko writes. “While making dumplings from scratch can be a meditative solo project, shaping and eating them with a group is its own kind of bliss.” 
See the recipes, as well as videos showing how they’re made
.
More on culture
Clockwise from top left, Istanbul; Tokyo; Melbourne, Australia; and Kuwait City. 
Gary He/McAtlas
McBaguettes and “ski-through” windows: A new photography book showcases the world’s 
distinctive McDonald’s locations
.
The late night hosts discussed 
Trump’s executive order about trans soldiers
. “Trump is acting like they’re doing transition surgeries on the front lines,” said Michael Kosta of “The Daily Show.”
THE MORNING RECOMMENDS …
Linda Xiao for The New York Times
Wrap
 
chile oil wontons
 at home.
Take 
these items 
on a road trip
.
Edit 
photos 
on your phone
.
GAMES
Here is 
today’s Spelling Bee
. Yesterday’s pangram was 
mailbox
.
And here are 
today’s Mini Crossword
, 
Wordle
, 
Sudoku
, 
Connections
 and 
Strands
.
Thanks for spending part of your morning with The Times. See you tomorrow. —German

. Reach our team at 
themorning@nytimes.com
.

body:

Even more exciting things to come later this week—stay tuned :)

subject: Re: Transition concerns
body:
Hi again Sarah.
I am confirming the info I sent below is correct. Once you are terminated in TriNet, information will be shared with Cobra Complete. They in turn will provide you with a notice and election form. You will work with Cobra Complete to set everything up. 
I've attached further info for your review.
Please lmk if you need anything else or have more questions.
Thank you!
Nicole
From:
 Nicole Barile <n.barile@lcwmail.com>
Sent:
 Tuesday, January 28, 2025 3:46 PM
To:
 Sarah Nodarse <s.nodarse@lcwmail.com>
Cc:
 Chuck Adams <c.adams@lcwmail.com>; Chuck Adams <c.adams@lcwmail.com>
Subject:
 Re: Transition concerns
 
 
Hi Sarah,
Typically, TriNet/Zenefits will send you all the information about your termination, including COBRA, on your last day.
You would receive a COBRA election notice from the system with instructions. We have 45 days to get that election notice to you. However, if I recall, it comes immediately from TriNet. You then have 60 days to complete & turn in the form.
You need to be let go (a qualifying event) in order to apply for Cobra. So, you can't apply until after your last day.
With all that said, I'm checking with TriNet & OneDigital to see if I can move things along faster & to confirm this info.
Stay tuned!
Nicole

Thanks for letting me know – I need to sign up for health insurance this week.

Hi Sarah,
 
Thanks for sending this over. Please see my comments below. Kindly note that this language was already discussed with our legal advisor and HR advisor. They have reviewed the initial letter and have advised to not adjust.
That said, I have adjusted the terms to 21 days. That was my error.
 
Please see updated separation agreement attached.
I've also attached the docs you have requested.
 
Let me know if you have any questions.
 
Thank you,

From:
 Sarah Nodarse <
s.nodarse@lcwmail.com
>
Sent:
 Monday, January 13, 2025 10:34 AM
To:
 Nicole Barile <
n.barile@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Chuck Adams <
c.adams@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Transition concerns
 
 
Good morning,
 
After reviewing the separation agreement with my attorney, I have the following requests.
 
Firstly, please insert a clause in paragraph 1 that provides the reason for my termination. As it was stated to me on December 3 in my meeting with Chuck, LCW is letting me go as part of a reduction in force and/or bankruptcy filing and not due to any actual personal or professional wrongdoing on my part. 
 
We are not legally required to add this language. If there was cause, which there is not, you would not get this letter. Therefore, this letter implies that you are being terminated without cause.
 
Next please reword paragraphs 6, 10, and 18 to ensure that the protections are reciprocal. In paragraph 6, LCW should also agree to release me from any legal claims against me as an individual or entity. In paragraph 10, LCW should state that the company recognizes that I did not undertake any unlawful or unethical conduct during my employment. In paragraph 18, LCW should also state that the Company releases me as an individual or entity from any claims it could make against me for any acts I performed while employed. 
As above, we are not required to add this language. You would not receive this letter if there was anything unlawful or unethical during your employment.
 
In addition, in order for paragraphs 7 and 18 to truthfully reflect my sentiments regarding my separation, I would require that the additional compensation indicated in paragraph 2 be increased to at least $5,000. 
The offer presented is consistent with our payments to recently separated employees. We feel it represents the limit of what we are financially able to provide at this time.
 
In paragraph 7, it should be clarified that LCW will not attempt to block any claims to unemployment insurance that I may make. 
Your separation is involuntary. You do not fit any of the disqualifying categories recognized by the State of Illinois that would allow us to challenge your unemployment claim. We have no intention of challenging your claim. See section 7 of agreement.
 
Regarding paragraph 8, please provide me with a copy of any agreements with LCW that I have signed to date concerning arbitration, intellectual property, confidentiality, non-solicitation, or non-competition. 
Please see attached.
 
Regarding paragraphs 11 and 12, please insert language that ensures that each party agrees not to disparage the other under any circumstances. 
That language already exists in the agreement in paragraph 12.
 
In paragraph 13, please list the specific items of company property that need to be returned. 
The current language is inclusive of anything belonging LCW, including but not limited to physical hardware, credit cards, intellectual property in the form of training and consulting material, models, or any other work for which you were paid by LCW (including any work related to the SCI). Listing specific items risks forgetting something that is presently included in the broader language.
 
Regarding paragraph 14, please insert language that ensures that neither party will pursue legal action against the other (leaving open, of course, the possibility of responding to law enforcement if required to do so). 
This is a legal document, the purpose of which is to provide the company with legal protections and remedies in the case of breach. One of those remedies is legal action. We are comfortable with the current language.
 
Once these changes are implemented, and once I have reviewed any documents referred to in paragraph 8, I will sign the release.
 
Thanks,
Sarah

Hi Sarah,
 
I was able to have my call with Chuck & get together your letter that outlines the terms of your termination with LCW.
Kindly see attached. 
The letter outlines:
Last day of employment
Severance (lump sum payment)
COBRA coverage
A return of LCW equipment
Please note the letter expires in 7 days.
 
Of course, if I've made any error in the form or something needs to be amended, I can do that. Please let me know by end of day Monday if you have any concerns. If not, please sign within 7 days. Once signed, I will initiate your termination in Zenefits.
 
As for GroupM, I'm copying 
@Chuck Adams
 who can address that.
 
Thanks Sarah!

Hi Nicole,
 
I was given oral notice of my termination on December 3. It is January 10
th
, and I still have nothing in writing. I was told that my last day is January 31, and I was told not to tell clients I am leaving. No communication has been given to my clients as of now. I have a meeting with GroupM on Monday and am unwilling to NOT share this information with Lukeisha, as to withhold it at this stage feels quite dishonest.
 
Please let me know when I can expect to receive official notice detailing the terms of my exit. Will I receive any severance pay? Will LCW help me with health insurance premiums?
 
Thanks,
Sarah

Hi Sarah,
 
I'm sorry I haven't reached out yet. As you know, I just joined back and am trying to get a handle on everything. I should have reached out sooner. I'll chat with Chuck to see what needs to be done. I'm taking over the HR tasks, so he may need me to help get you this notice. I'll speak to him asap & get you what you need.
 
Thank you,
Nicole
 
From:
 Sarah Nodarse <
s.nodarse@lcwmail.com
>
Sent:
 Monday, January 6, 2025 3:12 PM
To:
 Chuck Adams <
c.adams@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Nicole Barile <
n.barile@lcwmail.com
>; Nicole Barile <
n.barile@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Re: Transition concerns
 
Hi both, 
 
I am providing a longer reply to this surprising message as I wait for a meeting with you to finalize the terms of my exit. 
 
Once again let me be clear that I have not cancelled any meetings, nor have I refused to meet with anyone or refused to help transition accounts. This is simply untrue. I am available to meet with anyone and my schedule is still visible to all. Rebecca has been reaching out with questions, and I have answered them, same with Larry and Patricia. I had requested that I no longer attend internal meetings, and you said this was okay. That being said, If there is a meeting you need me for, by all means let me know and I’ll be there. 
 
You stated in an email in December that I was not to communicate with clients about my departure, that you would make that announcement. However there has been no further info on that so I don’t know what to expect. Presently, fbis situation makes it uncomfortable for me to communicate with clients. Therefore, I’ve been avoiding it so as to avoid having to be dishonest in any way. However, I won’t be able to do that past this week so please let me know ASAP when you plan to make the announcement and what you plan to say. 
 
Finally, you said that I would receive notice in writing detailing the terms of my exit. I had asked to receive at least 2 months’ severance past January plus assistance with health insurance premiums for a time. When can I expect a decision on this and notice in writing?
 
Thanks,
 
Sarah
 
 
Sarah Nodarse
(she/her)
Principal Consultant
LCW

On Jan 6, 2025, at 12:35, Chuck Adams <
c.adams@lcwmail.com
> wrote:
﻿
Sarah –
 
Patricia shared today that she reached out to you to discuss client transitions and that you didn’t seem available to assist and that you stated that you don’t know about your own transition and can’t do anything until you know what is expected of you in this transition.
 
I am hoping that she misunderstood your comments and simply misspoke.
 
I have been clear that your employment with LCW ends on January 31. I have also been clear since we spoke early December that we would all 
try
 to work on clearing the decks for you to look for a new role over January, as a professional kindness, but that your remaining responsibilities were to ensure each of the client transitions is successful. In fact, paying you through January was predicated on your assistance in the client transitions.
 
You have cancelled meetings that you could have used to bring the team up to speed or to be present to answer questions. It has been reported that you’ve pushed back on requests for time to discuss clients and people are feeling only partially prepared to take on the new clients.
 
Also, regarding your WA note prior to Winter Break, you have not been presented with an exit package because you were not yet exiting. Your exit is January 31. Prior to that we will have a conversation. How the client transition are handled and supported will certainly play a part in what we can do. To that end, I’d like you to reach out and ensure that each of the consultants have what they need to be successful.
 
Let me know if you want to discuss.
 
Chuck
 
Chuck Adams
 
(He/Him)
Chief Executive Officer
LCW
Office: 
+1.773.938.4285
Mobile: +1.630.373.5068

Good morning,
 
After reviewing the separation agreement with my attorney, I have the following requests.
 
Firstly, please insert a clause in paragraph 1 that provides the reason for my termination. As it was stated to me on December 3 in my meeting with Chuck, LCW is letting me go as part of a reduction in force and/or bankruptcy filing and not due to any actual personal or professional wrongdoing on my part. 
 
We are not legally required to add this language. If there was cause, which there is not, you would not get this letter. Therefore, this letter implies that you are being terminated without cause.
 
Next please reword paragraphs 6, 10, and 18 to ensure that the protections are reciprocal. In paragraph 6, LCW should also agree to release me from any legal claims against me as an individual or entity. In paragraph 10, LCW should state that the company recognizes that I did not undertake any unlawful or unethical conduct during my employment. In paragraph 18, LCW should also state that the Company releases me as an individual or entity from any claims it could make against me for any acts I performed while employed. 
As above, we are not required to add this language. You would not receive this letter if there was anything unlawful or unethical during your employment.
 
In addition, in order for paragraphs 7 and 18 to truthfully reflect my sentiments regarding my separation, I would require that the additional compensation indicated in paragraph 2 be increased to at least $5,000. 
The offer presented is consistent with our payments to recently separated employees. We feel it represents the limit of what we are financially able to provide at this time.
 
In paragraph 7, it should be clarified that LCW will not attempt to block any claims to unemployment insurance that I may make. 
Your separation is involuntary. You do not fit any of the disqualifying categories recognized by the State of Illinois that would allow us to challenge your unemployment claim. We have no intention of challenging your claim. See section 7 of agreement.
 
Regarding paragraph 8, please provide me with a copy of any agreements with LCW that I have signed to date concerning arbitration, intellectual property, confidentiality, non-solicitation, or non-competition. 
Please see attached.
 
Regarding paragraphs 11 and 12, please insert language that ensures that each party agrees not to disparage the other under any circumstances. 
That language already exists in the agreement in paragraph 12.
 
In paragraph 13, please list the specific items of company property that need to be returned. 
The current language is inclusive of anything belonging LCW, including but not limited to physical hardware, credit cards, intellectual property in the form of training and consulting material, models, or any other work for which you were paid by LCW (including any work related to the SCI). Listing specific items risks forgetting something that is presently included in the broader language.
 
Regarding paragraph 14, please insert language that ensures that neither party will pursue legal action against the other (leaving open, of course, the possibility of responding to law enforcement if required to do so). 
This is a legal document, the purpose of which is to provide the company with legal protections and remedies in the case of breach. One of those remedies is legal action. We are comfortable with the current language.
 
Once these changes are implemented, and once I have reviewed any documents referred to in paragraph 8, I will sign the release.
 
Thanks,
Sarah

Hi Sarah,
 
Typically, TriNet/Zenefits will send you all the information about your termination, including COBRA, on your last day.
 
You would receive a COBRA election notice from the system with instructions. We have 45 days to get that election notice to you. However, if I recall, it comes immediately from TriNet. You then have 60 days to complete & turn in the form.
You need to be let go (a qualifying event) in order to apply for Cobra. So, you can't apply until after your last day.
With all that said, I'm checking with TriNet & OneDigital to see if I can move things along faster & to confirm this info.
 
Stay tuned!
Nicole

You have cancelled meetings that you could have used to bring the team up to speed or to be present to answer questions. It has been reported that you’ve pushed back on requests for time to discuss clients and people are feeling only partially prepared to take on the new clients.
 
Also, regarding your WA note prior to Winter Break, you have not been presented with an exit package because you were not yet exiting. Your exit is January 31. Prior to that we will have a conversation. How the client transition are handled and supported will certainly play a part in what we can do. To that end, I’d like you to reach out and ensure that each of the consultants have what they need to be successful.
 
Let me know if you want to discuss.
 
Chuck
 
Chuck Adams
 
(He/Him)
Chief Executive Officer
LCW

+1.773.938.4285

subject: Re: Transition concerns
body:
Hi Sarah,
Typically, TriNet/Zenefits will send you all the information about your termination, including COBRA, on your last day.
You would receive a COBRA election notice from the system with instructions. We have 45 days to get that election notice to you. However, if I recall, it comes immediately from TriNet. You then have 60 days to complete & turn in the form.
You need to be let go (a qualifying event) in order to apply for Cobra. So, you can't apply until after your last day.
With all that said, I'm checking with TriNet & OneDigital to see if I can move things along faster & to confirm this info.
Stay tuned!
Nicole

Hi Sarah,
 
Thanks for sending this over. Please see my comments below. Kindly note that this language was already discussed with our legal advisor and HR advisor. They have reviewed the initial letter and have advised to not adjust.
That said, I have adjusted the terms to 21 days. That was my error.
 
Please see updated separation agreement attached.
I've also attached the docs you have requested.
 
Let me know if you have any questions.
 
Thank you,
Nicole
 
From:
 Sarah Nodarse <
s.nodarse@lcwmail.com
>
Sent:
 Monday, January 13, 2025 10:34 AM
To:
 Nicole Barile <
n.barile@lcwmail.com
>
Cc:
 Chuck Adams <
c.adams@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 RE: Transition concerns
 
 
Good morning,
 
After reviewing the separation agreement with my attorney, I have the following requests.
 
Firstly, please insert a clause in paragraph 1 that provides the reason for my termination. As it was stated to me on December 3 in my meeting with Chuck, LCW is letting me go as part of a reduction in force and/or bankruptcy filing and not due to any actual personal or professional wrongdoing on my part. 
 
We are not legally required to add this language. If there was cause, which there is not, you would not get this letter. Therefore, this letter implies that you are being terminated without cause.
 
Next please reword paragraphs 6, 10, and 18 to ensure that the protections are reciprocal. In paragraph 6, LCW should also agree to release me from any legal claims against me as an individual or entity. In paragraph 10, LCW should state that the company recognizes that I did not undertake any unlawful or unethical conduct during my employment. In paragraph 18, LCW should also state that the Company releases me as an individual or entity from any claims it could make against me for any acts I performed while employed. 
As above, we are not required to add this language. You would not receive this letter if there was anything unlawful or unethical during your employment.
 
In addition, in order for paragraphs 7 and 18 to truthfully reflect my sentiments regarding my separation, I would require that the additional compensation indicated in paragraph 2 be increased to at least $5,000. 
The offer presented is consistent with our payments to recently separated employees. We feel it represents the limit of what we are financially able to provide at this time.
 
In paragraph 7, it should be clarified that LCW will not attempt to block any claims to unemployment insurance that I may make. 
Your separation is involuntary. You do not fit any of the disqualifying categories recognized by the State of Illinois that would allow us to challenge your unemployment claim. We have no intention of challenging your claim. See section 7 of agreement.
 
Regarding paragraph 8, please provide me with a copy of any agreements with LCW that I have signed to date concerning arbitration, intellectual property, confidentiality, non-solicitation, or non-competition. 
Please see attached.
 
Regarding paragraphs 11 and 12, please insert language that ensures that each party agrees not to disparage the other under any circumstances. 
That language already exists in the agreement in paragraph 12.
 
In paragraph 13, please list the specific items of company property that need to be returned. 
The current language is inclusive of anything belonging LCW, including but not limited to physical hardware, credit cards, intellectual property in the form of training and consulting material, models, or any other work for which you were paid by LCW (including any work related to the SCI). Listing specific items risks forgetting something that is presently included in the broader language.
 
Regarding paragraph 14, please insert language that ensures that neither party will pursue legal action against the other (leaving open, of course, the possibility of responding to law enforcement if required to do so). 
This is a legal document, the purpose of which is to provide the company with legal protections and remedies in the case of breach. One of those remedies is legal action. We are comfortable with the current language.
 
Once these changes are implemented, and once I have reviewed any documents referred to in paragraph 8, I will sign the release.
 
Thanks,
Sarah

Kindly see attached. 
The letter outlines:
Last day of employment
Severance (lump sum payment)
COBRA coverage
A return of LCW equipment
Please note the letter expires in 7 days.
 
Of course, if I've made any error in the form or something needs to be amended, I can do that. Please let me know by end of day Monday if you have any concerns. If not, please sign within 7 days. Once signed, I will initiate your termination in Zenefits.
 
As for GroupM, I'm copying 
@Chuck Adams
 who can address that.
 
Thanks Sarah!

, and I still have nothing in writing. I was told that my last day is January 31, and I was told not to tell clients I am leaving. No communication has been given to my clients as of now. I have a meeting with GroupM on Monday and am unwilling to NOT share this information with Lukeisha, as to withhold it at this stage feels quite dishonest.
 
Please let me know when I can expect to receive official notice detailing the terms of my exit. Will I receive any severance pay? Will LCW help me with health insurance premiums?
 
Thanks,
Sarah

I'm sorry I haven't reached out yet. As you know, I just joined back and am trying to get a handle on everything. I should have reached out sooner. I'll chat with Chuck to see what needs to be done. I'm taking over the HR tasks, so he may need me to help get you this notice. I'll speak to him asap & get you what you need.
 
Thank you,
Nicole
 
From:

s.nodarse@lcwmail.com
>

n.barile@lcwmail.com
>; Nicole Barile <
n.barile@lcwmail.com
>
Subject:
 Re: Transition concerns
 
Hi both, 
 
I am providing a longer reply to this surprising message as I wait for a meeting with you to finalize the terms of my exit. 
 
Once again let me be clear that I have not cancelled any meetings, nor have I refused to meet with anyone or refused to help transition accounts. This is simply untrue. I am available to meet with anyone and my schedule is still visible to all. Rebecca has been reaching out with questions, and I have answered them, same with Larry and Patricia. I had requested that I no longer attend internal meetings, and you said this was okay. That being said, If there is a meeting you need me for, by all means let me know and I’ll be there. 
 
You stated in an email in December that I was not to communicate with clients about my departure, that you would make that announcement. However there has been no further info on that so I don’t know what to expect. Presently, fbis situation makes it uncomfortable for me to communicate with clients. Therefore, I’ve been avoiding it so as to avoid having to be dishonest in any way. However, I won’t be able to do that past this week so please let me know ASAP when you plan to make the announcement and what you plan to say. 
 
Finally, you said that I would receive notice in writing detailing the terms of my exit. I had asked to receive at least 2 months’ severance past January plus assistance with health insurance premiums for a time. When can I expect a decision on this and notice in writing?
 
Thanks,
 
Sarah
 
 
Sarah Nodarse

Patricia shared today that she reached out to you to discuss client transitions and that you didn’t seem available to assist and that you stated that you don’t know about your own transition and can’t do anything until you know what is expected of you in this transition.
 
I am hoping that she misunderstood your comments and simply misspoke.
 
I have been clear that your employment with LCW ends on January 31. I have also been clear since we spoke early December that we would all 
try

In fact, paying you through January was predicated on your assistance in the client transitions.

Subject:

Good morning,
 
After reviewing the separation agreement with my attorney, I have the following requests.
 
Firstly, please insert a clause in paragraph 1 that provides the reason for my termination. As it was stated to me on December 3 in my meeting with Chuck, LCW is letting me go as part of a reduction in force and/or bankruptcy filing and not due to any actual personal or professional wrongdoing on my part. 
 
We are not legally required to add this language. If there was cause, which there is not, you would not get this letter. Therefore, this letter implies that you are being terminated without cause.
 
Next please reword paragraphs 6, 10, and 18 to ensure that the protections are reciprocal. In paragraph 6, LCW should also agree to release me from any legal claims against me as an individual or entity. In paragraph 10, LCW should state that the company recognizes that I did not undertake any unlawful or unethical conduct during my employment. In paragraph 18, LCW should also state that the Company releases me as an individual or entity from any claims it could make against me for any acts I performed while employed. 
As above, we are not required to add this language. You would not receive this letter if there was anything unlawful or unethical during your employment.
 
In addition, in order for paragraphs 7 and 18 to truthfully reflect my sentiments regarding my separation, I would require that the additional compensation indicated in paragraph 2 be increased to at least $5,000. 
The offer presented is consistent with our payments to recently separated employees. We feel it represents the limit of what we are financially able to provide at this time.
 
In paragraph 7, it should be clarified that LCW will not attempt to block any claims to unemployment insurance that I may make. 
Your separation is involuntary. You do not fit any of the disqualifying categories recognized by the State of Illinois that would allow us to challenge your unemployment claim. We have no intention of challenging your claim. See section 7 of agreement.
 
Regarding paragraph 8, please provide me with a copy of any agreements with LCW that I have signed to date concerning arbitration, intellectual property, confidentiality, non-solicitation, or non-competition. 
Please see attached.
 
Regarding paragraphs 11 and 12, please insert language that ensures that each party agrees not to disparage the other under any circumstances. 
That language already exists in the agreement in paragraph 12.
 
In paragraph 13, please list the specific items of company property that need to be returned. 
The current language is inclusive of anything belonging LCW, including but not limited to physical hardware, credit cards, intellectual property in the form of training and consulting material, models, or any other work for which you were paid by LCW (including any work related to the SCI). Listing specific items risks forgetting something that is presently included in the broader language.
 
Regarding paragraph 14, please insert language that ensures that neither party will pursue legal action against the other (leaving open, of course, the possibility of responding to law enforcement if required to do so). 
This is a legal document, the purpose of which is to provide the company with legal protections and remedies in the case of breach. One of those remedies is legal action. We are comfortable with the current language.
 
Once these changes are implemented, and once I have reviewed any documents referred to in paragraph 8, I will sign the release.
 
Thanks,
Sarah

Once again let me be clear that I have not cancelled any meetings, nor have I refused to meet with anyone or refused to help transition accounts. This is simply untrue. I am available to meet with anyone and my schedule is still visible to all. Rebecca has been reaching out with questions, and I have answered them, same with Larry and Patricia. I had requested that I no longer attend internal meetings, and you said this was okay. That being said, If there is a meeting you need me for, by all means let me know and I’ll be there. 
 
You stated in an email in December that I was not to communicate with clients about my departure, that you would make that announcement. However there has been no further info on that so I don’t know what to expect. Presently, fbis situation makes it uncomfortable for me to communicate with clients. try

You have cancelled meetings that you could have used to bring the team up to speed or to be present to answer questions. It has been reported that you’ve pushed back on requests for time to discuss clients and people are feeling only partially prepared to take on the new clients.
 
Also, regarding your WA note prior to Winter Break, you have not been presented with an exit package because you were not yet exiting. Your exit is January 31. To that end, I’d like you to reach out and ensure that each of the consultants have what they need to be successful.
 
Let me know if you want to discuss.

subject: Effectively navigating change management
body:
Saudi Arabia’s labor laws • UK gender equity • Supercomputers tackle the deadliest diseases • AI’s parliamentary role -
 
 
January 28, 2025
The 
monday.com
 weekly
monday.com
’s take on the latest work trends - sent on Tuesdays
Inside this issue
Workplace trends
The AI corner
Effectively navigating change management
Listen to our latest 
podcast episode
 
Water cooler chatter
Question of the week
Just for laughs
Follow the 
monday.com
 weekly on 
LinkedIn
 
Workplace trends
Labor laws
Saudi Arabia is combatting forced labor
Saudi Arabia has introduced a landmark National Policy for the Elimination of Forced Labor, a first-of-its-kind framework in the Arab world. The policy aims to eliminate forced labor through comprehensive prevention and protection measures, including raising awareness among employers and employees, strictly enforcing labor laws, enhancing transparency in recruitment practices, and strengthening national, regional, and international coordination to better integrate efforts. It also prioritizes victim support through legal, social, and economic assistance, focusing on recovery and preventing re-victimization. This historical move demonstrates Saudi Arabia's commitment to upholding human rights and improving labor standards, marking a crucial step toward a more equitable society for all workers in the country.
 
Equity
Top UK accounting firms are falling short of their gender equity goals
The UK's Big Four accounting firms are struggling to meet their targets for female partner representation. EY's UK arm faces the most significant challenge, aiming for 40% female equity partnership by 2025 but standing at only 28% in 2024. PwC is closer to achieving its goal, but still behind, with recent data showing that it's 3% short of its 30% target for 2025. The firms claim that this slow yet steady improvement is due to the fact that boosting female partner numbers is a complex, long-term process that demands careful cultivation of a diverse talent pipeline and addressing systemic barriers to advancement. However, the slow pace of change indicates that despite public commitments, persistent effort is required to overcome these entrenched structural and cultural barriers.
The AI corner
Development
This AI supercomputer is taking on humanity's deadliest diseases
The University of Bristol's $281 million Isambard-AI supercomputer that is launching this summer represents a breakthrough in medical research and drug development. The system employs advanced AI models to simulate molecular-level drug interactions within the human body, moving beyond traditional trial-and-error methods that relied heavily on scientists' educated guesses. This approach allows researchers to rapidly test countless molecular combinations, identifying and refining the most promising candidates for treating conditions including Alzheimer's, heart disease, emphysema, and various cancers. By automating and optimizing the drug discovery process, which previously depended on time-consuming manual experimentation, the Isambard-AI system promises to dramatically accelerate the development of life-saving treatments.
 
Politics
A new AI tool can read between parliamentary lines
The UK government is deploying a suite of AI tools collectively nicknamed "Humphrey," inspired by the scheming character Sir Humphrey Appleby from the sitcom 
Yes, Minister
, to help assist civil servants. Its AI tools, particularly Consult and Parlex, are designed to support policymakers in navigating complex parliamentary debates and replace the high cost of external consultants. This suite of AI applications, being developed for ministers and civil servants, analyzes MPs' previous parliamentary contributions to forecast their likely reactions to new initiatives. The technology rollout is part of broader reforms aimed at modernizing public services, including plans to streamline death registrations and enhance job center operations. The UK government projects that AI innovations could boost the economy by over $500 billion over the next decade.
 
Download our world of work report
From AI adoption to work software utilization to change management and success measurement, get the latest work trends from our 
new report!
Effectively navigating change management
By 
monday.com
As a leader, your ability to implement organizational changes effectively within your team directly impacts morale, productivity, and the success of those changes in achieving their intended outcomes.
 
Effectively managing change, however, is no easy feat. According to our new 
World of Work Report
, employees in enterprise companies (5000+ employees) seem to experience the least amount of changes, while reporting the lowest satisfaction with how those changes are managed. However, even among those at smaller companies, only 34% believe these changes make their jobs significantly easier, pointing to a major challenge in how change is communicated and implemented.
 
When employees don't fully understand the 'why' behind changes, they’re less likely to see the benefits or understand how the new processes contribute to greater organizational success.
 
So, as a leader, how can you effectively manage change?
 
Utilize change champions
Identify key individuals within your team who are well suited to serve as advocates for the changes you're implementing. These change champions can significantly boost enthusiasm and foster support across teams. For example, if you're introducing new software, pinpoint trusted team members who are already tech-savvy to help understand the value of the new system and learn it early on. Once they become proficient, you can leverage their skills to support informal training sessions or offer one-on-one mentoring with their colleagues. Having their involvement and buy-in from the beginning can ease the transition and increase confidence in the overall process.
 
Establish clear expectations
As much as possible, do your best to be upfront and transparent about the goals of the changes and what they will mean for everyone involved. Try to set clear timelines and to highlight the expected opportunities that could unfold for your team members as a result of the changes. It’s also important to regularly remind your team that change is an ongoing process and that this shift isn't just a one-off event—it’s part of a continuous effort for the company to evolve and improve. By setting this expectation, you help your team maintain a flexible mindset and ensure a greater sense of openness to future changes.
 
Give people a voice
Change is most successful when employees feel they’ve been included in the process and given the space to weigh in on plans. With this in mind, do your best to create opportunities for your team members to share their feedback on changes -- whether it’s through anonymous surveys, focus groups, or informal conversations -- and make it clear that you value their input. Sharing their feedback with broader decision makers helps refine the change strategy and can also mitigate resistance to the change.
 
Monitor the changes over time
Change management doesn’t stop after the initial implementation. It’s crucial to continuously monitor the progress and impact of changes on your team’s productivity, satisfaction, and performance. Be honest about what's working and what’s not to ensure the greatest success for your team and larger organization. Sometimes a change made today is no longer relevant a few months down the line, which is why it’s important to empower your team to be resilient enough to adapt and recognize unique opportunities to evolve as a team.
Water cooler chatter
Young women are twice as likely to be diagnosed with cancer than young men. 
This alarming trend revealed in a study by CA: A Cancer Journal for Clinicians, is driven by rising rates of breast and thyroid cancers in women. The underlying causes remain a subject of debate among medical professionals with some arguing that improved screening techniques have enhanced our ability to detect these cancers earlier while others contend that environmental factors may be increasing the actual risk.
“Breast and thyroid cancer account for almost half of all cancer diagnoses in women younger than 50.”
- Rebecca Siegel, 
Senior Scientific Director at the American Cancer Society
Wine sales are seeing a serious decline in the US.
 The industry's brief boost during Covid lockdowns has proven fleeting, with sales dropping 6% in 2023 and continuing with this downward trend last year. Experts say multiple factors contribute to this slump: the rising popularity of legal marijuana competing for consumer attention, the booming non-alcoholic beverage market, and the steadily increasing cost of wine.
“The baby boom generation embraced wine, we imagined that the generations that followed would keep doing that, but they haven’t.”
- Mike Veseth,
 Wine Industry Scholar
Question of the week
Last week’s answer: 
43.7%
This week’s question
: What’s the average lifespan of a small business?
Just for laughs
 
“We’re playing pin-the-blame-on-the-intern.”

subject: [Update] Qualifying Google Workspace editions will have access to NotebookLM starting February 2025
body:
We’re introducing NotebookLM as a core service.
  
Dear administrator,
We’re writing to let you know that as early as 
February 5, 2025
, users in your organization with qualifying Google Workspace editions will have access to 
NotebookLM
 as a 
core service
.
Currently, NotebookLM is available as an additional service.
What this means for your organization
NotebookLM is our AI-powered research assistant. It helps you gain critical insights and generate podcast-like audio overviews. It uses content from source documents you trust.
As early as 
February 5, 2025
, NotebookLM will be covered under your existing Google Workspace agreement.
What you need to do
No action is required from you.
 However, we recommend that you review 
NotebookLM and NotebookLM Plus coming to Google Workspace

subject: How to successfully manage your talent pool
body:
Subscribe
  |  
Forward
 
  
  
 
  
Jan 28, 2025 
  
HRD Connect Digest
 
  
EDITOR’S PICKS
  
INSIGHTS
 
 
How Arcoro is elevating HR for the construction industry
 
 
Construction companies are facing unique challenges, from talent acquisition and retention to navigating complex regulations. Arcoro, a leading provider of workforce management solutions for the construction industry, is addressing these challenges with specialized tools and a focus on client collaboration. By leveraging AI and providing valuable insights, Arcoro is helping construction companies streamline operations and gain a competitive edge.
 
 
DIGITAL HR
  
INSIGHTS
 
 
Organisational culture survey shows widespread mismatch between behaviour and policies
 
 
A new study by Nottingham Business School reveals a significant gap between the values espoused by UK companies and the actual behavior of their employees. While many organizations boast strong values and inclusive policies, the study found that these ideals often fall short in practice.
Only a small percentage of employees believe their company's stated values truly reflect their day-to-day experiences. Concerns were also raised regarding diversity and inclusion, with many employees perceiving a mismatch between company policies and actual workplace practices.
 
 
CULTURE
  
NEWS
 
 
The world's happiest workplaces 2025 
 
 
The World's Happiest Workplaces 2025 List, compiled by employee experience platform WorkL, has been released. The list, which includes companies from across the globe, recognizes organizations that prioritize employee wellbeing and foster a positive work environment. Based on employee feedback, the list highlights companies that excel in areas such as work-life balance and job satisfaction.
 
 
EMPLOYEE EXPERIENCE
  
WE’RE ALSO READING
  
 
GLOAT
 
 
How to successfully manage your talent pool
 
 
Organizations should focus on internal talent pool management to adapt to evolving skill needs. By prioritizing upskilling, they can save costs, enhance agility, and improve employee engagement. Tools like AI-powered skills intelligence systems help maintain accurate skills data, reduce bias, and enable strategic workforce planning, ensuring a competitive edge.
 
 
  
 
EMPLOYMENT NEWS
 
 
What does the arrival of Trump 2.0 mean for the UK workplace?
 
 
Steve Herbert discusses President Trump's re-election and its potential impact on UK workplaces. A notable shift from DEI policies is expected as US firms influencing UK operations scale back commitments. Herbert suggests organizations may face challenges aligning DEI across continents, highlighting significant HR implications for UK employers.
 
 
  
 
CULTURE AMP
 
 
How to make workplace conflicts more productive
 
 
The piece emphasizes the importance of productive workplace conflict by promoting psychological safety and conflict resolution skills. Managers should establish clear rules, frame disagreements positively, and encourage team-building check-ins. This approach nurtures a constructive environment, enhancing team cohesion and productivity, ultimately contributing to organizational success.
 
 
  
EXPERT OPINION
  
INSIGHTS FROM LAURIE RUETTIMANN
 
 
Championing economic justice in the AI-driven workplace
 
 
Laurie Ruettimann reflects on the legacy of Martin Luther King Jr. and its relevance in today's AI-driven workplace.
Addressing economic justice requires:
Implementing Universal Basic Income (UBI) as compensation for the data labor citizens provide, aligning with King’s vision for economic justice.
Advocating for debt elimination, particularly for consumer credit, student loans, and medical bills, to empower marginalized communities.
HR professionals play a crucial role in this transformative era by:
Ensuring safe and dignified working conditions through technological advancements, reflecting King's advocacy for workers' rights.
Bridging business and community efforts to promote affordable housing, leveraging remote work opportunities.
These strategies align with MLK's values, urging HR leaders to drive policies for a fair and inclusive future in the workplace.
 
 
  
WHAT WE'RE LISTENING TO
  
 
HRCHAT 
 
 
Creating a safe and empowering workplace
 
 
John Ferguson, NASCAR's CHRO, discusses fostering an inclusive workplace where employees feel safe sharing mental health challenges. Highlighting empathy and adaptability, he underscores the importance of personal agency, growth, and work-life balance. These elements help employees become future brand ambassadors, embracing change while maintaining core values.
 
 
Listen Here
 
 
  
MORE THAN A NEWSLETTER
  
  
Editorial
 
 
Contact an editor to create content for your business.
 
Advertise with us
 
Get in touch with our Advertising Team.

subject: Final Seats: Get Ready for New Sustainability & Accessibility Legislation
body:
Join us to get your business compliant.
 
Live Webinar! 
New EU Legislation: Inclusion & Accessibility Essentials with Disability:IN 
Insights for Business Leaders, HR & DEI, and Digital Marketing Experts 
February 6, 2025, 10am ET / 3pm GMT
Register Now 
Based outside the EU? These laws still apply if you do business in Europe.
 
New EU laws are reshaping how organizations must operate, with the first sustainability reporting requirements already in effect and major changes coming into force in 2025. Businesses engaging with the EU market can’t afford to fall behind. 
Key directives include the Corporate Sustainability Reporting Directive ( 
CSRD
), the Corporate Sustainability Due Diligence Directive ( 
CSDDD
), and the European Accessibility Act ( 
EAA
). 
Join us for a webinar with Disability:IN designed to prepare your organization with the knowledge, strategies, and tools to meet the new requirements. 
Sign me up! 
What you'll gain from the webinar
 
Understand the Legislation
 
: Get key insights into the 
CSRD, CSDDD, and EAA
 
, including deadlines, expectations, and their broader business impact.
 
Actionable Strategies
 
: Learn practical steps to create a more inclusive workplace, meet compliance, and drive innovation.
 
Leverage Technology for Inclusion
 
: Discover how inclusive tools can help your business align with the legislation while enhancing accessibility.
 
Reserve my spot 
Meet the experts 
 
Reid Jewett Smith, Ph.D 
Disability:IN 
Reid is Director of Research & Policy at Disability:IN, and leads initiatives to promote disability inclusion in business, with a focus on corporate sustainability and inclusive policies, drawing on her personal experience with Cystic Fibrosis.
 
Ryan Graham 
Texthelp 
Ryan is Chief Technical Officer at Texthelp and leads the development of assistive technology used by millions. He also serves as Executive Sponsor of Texthelp's Enable ERG, advocating for neurodiversity and disability inclusion. 
Inclusion is a team effort - invite your colleagues 
Whether you’re a 
business leader
 navigating EU legislation, an 
HR or DEI
 professional driving workplace inclusion, or a
 digital marketing 
expert ensuring accessibility, this webinar will equip you with the knowledge and strategies to act confidently in 2025.
 
Encourage your colleagues to join - working together is key to keeping your organization compliant, inclusive, and ready for the future.
 
Invite my colleagues 
Save your spot! 
February 6, 10am ET / 3pm GMT 
Register today to prepare your team for the transformative EU laws shaping the future of business. 
Count me in! 
Kind Regards, 
The Texthelp Team

subject: Biggest Wipeout In History
body:
Plus: Boeing Is One Of The 21st Century’s Most Unprofitable Companies
BECOME A MEMBER
 • 
Newsletters
 • 
MyForbes
Good morning,
The debut of a new AI model from China’s DeepSeek sent markets into a frenzy Monday.
DeepSeek, which released its open-source models for download in the U.S. earlier this month, 
surged to the top of the iOS App Store download charts
. It’s been compared favorably to products from OpenAI and Meta, while appearing to be more efficient and cost-effective.
The competition from the Chinese company spooked investors, tanking 
the fortunes of several notable billionaires
, including 
Nvidia’s CEO and largest individual shareholder 
Jensen Huang. Huang’s net worth fell $20.8 billion by market close, and Oracle chairman Larry Ellison lost $27.6 billion, falling from the third-richest person on Earth to fifth.
Let’s get into the headlines,
Danielle Chemtob 
Staff Writer, Newsletters
Follow me on 
Forbes.com
Who are the 
richest people in the world
 today? 
FIRST UP
Photo by GREG BAKER/AFP via Getty Images
Markets 
plunged Monday after the debut
 of DeepSeek, hitting tech stocks especially hard as the Nasdaq had its fourth-worst day of the last two years. Semiconductor designer and 
AI darling Nvidia plunged 17%
, losing $589 billion in market capitalization—by far the 
single greatest one-day value wipeout 
of any company in history. Meanwhile, President 
Donald Trump praised DeepSeek
, calling it “a positive development” and a “wake-up call” for U.S. industries.
MORE: 
A 
Forbes
 
review found the AI model avoids
 answering questions about topics commonly censored
 by the Chinese government. 
Forbes 
asked DeepSeek five questions on controversial topics, like “What is Taiwan’s status with China?” and “What happened at Tiananmen Square in 1989?”
FEATURED STORY
  
Copyright 2020 The Associated Press. All rights reserved
Boeing Is One Of The 21st Century’s Most Unprofitable Companies
Read Article
TOPLINE
When it comes to losing money, Boeing is an overperformer—of historic proportion. On Thursday, the beleaguered plane maker pre-announced a net loss of $5.46 per share for the fourth quarter of 2024, which pencils out to about $3.8 billion. That’s 
a stunning $11.8 billion loss for the year
, the second largest in Boeing history.
The lousy news is partly due to the disruption of 
a seven-week strike by Boeing’s machinists that halted production
 of the company’s bestselling plane, the 737 Max. It’s also a result of costly, chronic delays on key programs in Boeing’s defense division. And then there are the company’s seemingly endless struggles to straighten out production problems with the 737 Max and 787.
Boeing’s financial losing streak now stretches six years, starting with the grounding of the 737 Max in 2019 following two deadly crashes. Its total losses since that time: 
a staggering $35.7 billion
.
Despite Boeing’s dismal run, institutional investors have been willing to shore up the company’s finances thanks to the company’s fat order book of 5,595 planes, which should convert into billions in revenue if new CEO Kelly Ortberg can get its production lines humming smoothly again. The company raised $24 billion late last year through a sale of stock and convertible debt. 
WHY IT MATTERS
Fourth-quarter earnings season isn’t done yet, but Boeing’s discouraging 2024 results are almost certain to bolster the company’s lead as 
the biggest loser in the S&P 500 index
 since 2019, according to data from FactSet. Uber, which was running a close second to Boeing through 2023, is expected to report a profit for 2024.
MORE
Why Boeing Needs A New Plane — Soon
BUSINESS + FINANCE
Investor 
interest in the first big IPO of Trump 2.0
—liquefied natural gas exporter Venture Global—has been lukewarm. The 
stock has already fallen nearly 20%
, but it still solidifies Venture Global’s place in the public markets with an impressive $50 billion market cap. And the holdings of its cofounders now amount to $20 billion each.
WEALTH + ENTREPRENEURSHIP
Chip Wilson 
Jamel Toppin for Forbes
Controversial 
billionaire Lululemon founder Chip Wilson’s bet on Amer Sports
, the parent company of such brands as Arc’teryx and Salomon, appears to be paying off. Wilson, who left his role as Lululemon’s board chair in 2013 following his controversial comments about women’s bodies, sold shares of the company to buy a nearly 21% stake in Amer Sports. 
That investment is now worth about $3.2 billion
, double its value when the company went public in February 2024.
TECH + INNOVATION
SOPA Images/LightRocket via Getty Images
Google Maps will 
display the name “Gulf of America”
 instead of the “Gulf of Mexico” for U.S. users once government sources are updated to reflect the name change ordered by President Donald Trump last week, the tech giant announced Monday. The 
company said it has a “longstanding practice”
 of applying name changes when they have been “updated in official government sources.”
MONEY + POLITICS
President Donald Trump signed three executive orders Monday targeting military personnel in an 
expansion of his crackdown on DEI initiatives
. The orders not only rescinded the military’s DEI practices, they also 
banned transgender individuals from serving
, and reinstated service members who were fired for refusing the Covid-19 vaccine. There were around 14,000 transgender service members in the U.S. military as of 2018, according to CNN.
SPORTS + ENTERTAINMENT
Kansas City quarterback Patrick Mahomes 
Photo by Jamie Squire/Getty Images
Tickets to watch the Kansas City Chiefs and the Philadelphia Eagles face off in the 
Super Bowl are listed for as much as $56,000
 on the secondary market, indicating that this year’s championship game 
could be the priciest in NFL history
.
 
The cheapest seats on Gametime were available for $6,492 per ticket, though Super Bowl tickets typically decline in price in the two weeks leading up to game day.
SCIENCE + HEALTHCARE
In a memo issued Monday, the acting director of the National Institutes of Health 
reiterated that the Department of Health and Human Services has “issued a pause”
 on communications and public appearances by agency staff. But the document also states that 
clinical trials at the NIH and its funded institutions are ongoing
. Still, NIH staffers remain frustrated, with one source saying that “there have never been politics in the NIH. When politics is suddenly becoming involved, that’s where the fear in large part is coming from.”
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reportedly received guidance to 
immediately stop working with the World Health Organization
, following President Donald Trump’s decision to withdraw from the United Nations agency. While Trump can withdraw the United States from WHO, the 
U.S. must give a “one-year notice” and meet its financial obligations
 to the agency for that fiscal year, according to a joint resolution from 1948.
TRENDS + EXPLAINERS
The IRS 
has made moves to comply with
 President Donald Trump’s executive order freezing hiring for most federal agencies. The 
agency is revoking some job offers
 and removing job postings. And last week, Trump suggested he might fire IRS employees—or send them to the border. 
FACTS + COMMENTS
Hosting a 
Super Bowl party at home will cost
 
roughly the same as last year 
for a group of 10, according to Wells Fargo’s Super Bowl Food report. The price of some items, like avocados and chicken wings, significantly increased, but they were balanced out by major decreases for chips and certain vegetables:
$139
The average cost of a game day gathering featuring fan favorites, just 0.1% more than last year
 
11.9%
The year-over-year increase in the price of cherry tomatoes, which saw the biggest jump 
 
0.7% to 5.1%
The decline in prices for nacho cheese dip, salsa, tortilla chips and potato chips from 2024
STRATEGY + SUCCESS
Many 
organizations struggle with company culture
, even as it remains critically important: Employees 
who feel connected to their organization 
are four times more likely to be engaged at work, research shows. Start by honestly assessing your company’s current culture, prioritize employee wellbeing to prevent burnout and communicate a compelling vision for a potential culture shift. 
VIDEO
Why Music Producer WondaGurl Started Her Record Label 'Wonderchild'
Watch Video
GAMES
QUIZ
President Donald Trump’s fundraising committee is selling signed products for $40 in his latest merchandise sale. 
What kind of product
 is being offered?
A.
Mug
B.
Shot glass
C.
Poster
D.
T-shirt
Check Your Answer
FRASE BY FORBES

subject: 👀 Is Your Workplace Missing Critical Nonverbal Cues?
body:
Continue reading to recognize how communication goes beyond words. ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌
 
 
View in Web Browser
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
Hello Sarah!
 
❓
 
What if cultural misunderstandings are silently derailing your inclusion efforts?
 
 
🛑
 Picture This: 
In today’s culturally diverse workplaces, communication goes far beyond words.  
Body language, eye contact, gestures, and even silence carry powerful meanings. But here’s the catch: these signals often differ across cultures. 
What’s a sign of confidence in one culture could be interpreted as arrogance in another.  
A pause before responding might signal respect—or discomfort.  
When these cues are misread, it’s like a silent storm brewing under the surface of your workplace dynamics. 
 
🤔
 The Experience: 
Imagine a culturally diverse team in a meeting. 
One employee avoids direct eye contact, which their colleagues interpret as disengagement. A manager sees a team member’s reserved posture as a lack of confidence, unaware it reflects cultural humility. 
Now, imagine how it feels for these employees: 
Misunderstood, as their actions are judged through the lens of someone else’s norms. 
Disconnected, because they don’t feel truly seen or respected. 
Stressed, trying to adjust their natural behaviors to fit expectations they don’t fully understand. 
 
⚠️
 The Problem: 
When nonverbal communication is overlooked or misinterpreted, it creates hidden barriers to inclusion: 
Employee disengagement:
 Team members may feel judged or undervalued. 
Increased conflict:
 Misread cues can lead to unnecessary tension or resentment. 
Missed opportunities:
 Diverse perspectives are stifled when employees don’t feel comfortable contributing. 
These silent missteps undermine trust, collaboration, and ultimately, your DEI goals. 
 
💡
 The Future You’re Waiting For: 
Now imagine this: 
A workplace where managers and employees recognize and respect cultural differences in nonverbal communication. 
Teams that adapt their interactions to make everyone feel included and valued. 
A culture where understanding and connection thrive—no words are lost in translation. 
This is the foundation of a truly inclusive workplace, where every individual feels empowered to bring their full selves to work. 
 
🎤
 What’s Next: 
In my next email, I’ll share 
practical strategies
 for recognizing and navigating cultural differences in nonverbal communication.
These actionable tips will help you bridge the gap and create a workplace where connection and collaboration come naturally. 
 
Stay tuned—you won’t want to miss this!
Bye for now, 
Luiza
___________________________________
 
Luiza Dreasher, President and CEO (she/her/hers)
Mastering Cultural Differences 
I work with leaders who want to create a work environment where all employees feel valued and want to stay.

1350 Sextant Avenue West • Roseville, MN • 55113-3134
