subject: Bloomberg Steps In
body:
Plus: With NIH In Chaos, Scientists Fear Trump Will Hamstring Critical Medical Research
BECOME A MEMBER
 • 
Newsletters
 • 
MyForbes
Good morning,
The next time you need to order groceries or purchase tickets, AI might be able to save you some time.
OpenAI 
unveiled its latest tool, “Operator,”
 an 
AI assistant designed to carry out a wide variety of tasks
. Operator can navigate web pages and interact with buttons and menus, though OpenAI noted it’s not fully autonomous and users may need to input information like passwords. The tool is currently only available to users on the ChatGPT Pro plan, which costs $200 a month, though the company plans to expand Operator to other subscriptions.
It’s part of the AI juggernaut’s move toward artificial general intelligence, the idea that AI could eventually match the cognitive abilities of humans.
Let’s get into the headlines,
Danielle Chemtob 
Staff Writer, Newsletters
Follow me on 
Forbes.com
Who are the 
richest people in the world
 today? 
FIRST UP
Getty Images for Bloomberg Philanthropies
Billionaire 
Michael Bloomberg announced Thursday that Bloomberg Philanthropies
 will 
step in to help fund the United Nations’ climate change work 
after President Donald Trump withdrew from the Paris Climate Agreement. Bloomberg, the former mayor of New York City, cofounder of Bloomberg Media and special envoy to the UN, also helped cover the U.S.’ portion of its climate commitments to the UN from 2017 to 2020 after Trump withdrew from the Paris Agreement for the first time.
A federal 
judge granted a request from Democratic-led states
 to pause President 
Donald Trump’s executive order ending “birthright citizenship” 
while litigation moves forward, describing the order as “blatantly unconstitutional.” Trump’s executive order states that in 30 days, anyone born to parents who are not citizens or permanent U.S. residents will not automatically be granted citizenship—even if their parents are in the U.S. legally, such as on student visas or work visas.
DAILY COVER STORY
  
Illustration by Yunjia Yuan for Forbes; Photos by Getty Images: Andrew Harnik; SimoneN; Javier Zayas; AlexandrMoroz; Vicente Méndez; John M Lund
With NIH In Chaos, Scientists Fear Trump Will Hamstring Critical Medical Research
Read Article
TOPLINE
On Wednesday around 1:30 p.m. Pacific time, Esther Choo, a professor of emergency medicine at Oregon Health & Science University, got an email that the National Institutes of Health study section she was slated to sit on the next day was cancelled. Within hours, as word of NIH meeting cancellations pinged across the social media platform Bluesky, she realized that this wasn’t only about the opioid research she would be reviewing, but
 a broader NIH research shutdown.
The NIH is the crown jewel of American scientific research, investing 
most of its $47 billion budget on medical research. 
Without the NIH meetings known as study sections, the agency can’t review grants and thus can’t make research awards. Those funds are critically important in helping researchers study cancer, Alzheimer’s disease, diabetes and opioid addiction, among numerous other health issues – and have helped fund major breakthroughs, including Moderna’s development of its mRNA vaccine against Covid-19. Vaccinations against Covid-19  saved at least 14 million people from dying in the first year.
In the short-term, the cancellation of these meetings means that some researchers who expect to receive funds in January will see those funds delayed, while others who had expected grant proposals slated to be reviewed would be subject to the challenges of rescheduling once the pause is lifted. It’s not clear if NIH grant review meetings will resume after February 1, when the pause on federal health communications is slated to end.
Longer term, researchers fear the Trump Administration will use federal research funding as a 
cudgel to force universities and other institutions 
that receive it in its purge of diversity, equity and inclusion efforts. 
WHY IT MATTERS
“This pause in grant reviews jeopardizes not just my career, but
 the progress of our field
,” Sema Quadir, a postdoctoral research scholar studying alcohol use disorder at the Northwestern University Feinberg School of Medicine, told 
Forbes.
 “What happens to the researchers whose work is delayed indefinitely? And what happens to the 46 million people in the U.S. living with a substance use disorder, waiting for breakthroughs that depend on federally funded research?”
 
MORE
Trump Administration Delays Funding To Cancer Research
BUSINESS + FINANCE
JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon 
Getty Images
President Donald Trump’s executive order designed to dismantle diversity, equity and inclusion programs in the federal government 
also alludes to potential legal action against private entities
 with these programs, and some companies are already taking pre-emptive actions. New York University lawyer Kenji Yoshino told the
 New York Times
 that the orders are
 “a way of striking fear into organizations’ hearts.” 
Walmart, Ford, McDonald’s, Meta, Amazon and a host of other major corporations have taken steps back on DEI and DEI-adjacent initiatives.
MORE: 
JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon 
stood by his bank’s DEI
 efforts, despite
 facing challenges from conservative activist shareholders 
and the Trump Administration’s recent crackdown. JPMorgan has developed a comprehensive suite of diversity-focused programs, which Dimon sees as sound business strategy rather than a charitable effort. 
Blockstream, led by cryptography pioneer and Satoshi Nakamoto’s first collaborator Adam Back, is 
making a move into asset management
 with a set of funds under its new Blockstream Asset Management division. Though investors now have 
access to a variety of crypto-adjacent funds
, the menu for comprehensive, risk-managed lending strategies—especially for institutions and accredited investors—remains limited. Blockstream wants to fill that gap.
TECH + INNOVATION
Federal 
prosecutors in San Francisco said Thursday
 that the founder of venture-backed AI chat startup On
 allegedly used over $4 million of investor funds 
to purchase a home, fund private schools, buy luxury cars, and even pay for his wedding venue. Alex Beckman, the former CEO of the company, which raised $125 million from VCs and sports stars like Joe Montana and André Iguodala, is now being charged with wire fraud, along with his wife Valerie Lau Beckman.
Hive, a $2 billion content moderation company, uses 
machine learning models to flag harmful content
 on the internet, and a new partnership with a U.K.-based child safety nonprofit will better equip the startup to 
identify and remove child sexual abuse material 
from its customers’ websites. The new partnership aims to stem the flood of such AI-generated images, of which offenders created tens of thousands in 2024. 
MONEY + POLITICS
The 
Justice Department ordered its civil rights division
 to 
pause ongoing litigation and not engage
 in any new cases, according to the
 Washington Post
. The memo reportedly says the pause, which will freeze litigation linked to the Biden Administration, is being implemented to “ensure that the President’s appointees or designees have the opportunity to decide whether to initiate any new cases.”
SPORTS + ENTERTAINMENT
Zoe Saldana, Adriana Paz, Karla Sofia Gascon and Selena Gomez attend the "Emilia Pérez" premiere.
 Photo by Dominik Bindl/WireImage
The 
Academy announced Oscar nominations
 Thursday, and the 
divisive Spanish-language French crime musical 
Emilia Pérez
 led
 with 13 nominations. The Vatican drama 
Conclave
 earned eight nominations but missed out on several crucial nods that were expected, including a nomination for director Edward Berger. The 97th Academy Awards will air March 2 at 7 p.m. EST.
TRENDS + EXPLAINERS
The CEO of the Anti-Defamation League 
blasted Elon Musk on Thursday for a series
 of 
Holocaust-related jokes he posted on X
, just days after the nonprofit defended the billionaire’s use of what many have said closely resembles a Nazi salute and calling it an “awkward gesture.” Jonathan Greenblatt, CEO of the ADL, responded to a series of puns Musk posted evoking the names of famous Nazi party members, saying “The Holocaust was a singularly evil event, and it is inappropriate and offensive to make light of it.”
FACTS + COMMENTS
President Donald Trump ordered a 
U.S. withdrawal from a global tax deal
, among his 
directives focused on global tax and trade policy
. The two pillars of the global tax efforts focus on where tax should be paid and the amount: 
140
The number of countries that have agreed in theory to the pillars, which included the U.S. until recently
 
15%
The global minimum corporate tax rate that would be established under Pillar Two agreement
 
‘No force or effect within the United States’
A presidential memorandum said of any commitments made by the prior administration in relation to the Global Tax Deal
STRATEGY + SUCCESS
Many professionals face the decision at some point whether to accept a 
promotion that doesn’t come with an increase
 in pay. Resist the urge to act on a knee-jerk reaction, and assess the offer objectively. While it can be worth it if the title will boost your overall career prospects,
 be wary of vague promises
 like that it’s a “stepping stone” or your salary will be “revisited” later. Refusing a promotion in some cases is the smartest move, especially if the role comes with significantly more responsibilities, higher expectations, and no clear payoff.
VIDEO
How Dick's Sporting Goods Is Using Data To Beat Its Competitors
Watch Video
GAMES
QUIZ
A slew of celebrities will fill the commercial airtime during this year’s Super Bowl. Daytime TV host Drew Barrymore will star in the first-ever Super Bowl commercial for 
which cruise brand?
A.
Royal Caribbean
B.
Norwegian
C.
MSC Cruises
D.
Virgin Voyages
Check Your Answer

.

.

subject: The Morning: Why tariffs are different
body:
Plus, immigration, abortion pills and podcasts.
View in browser
|
nytimes.com
January 24, 2025
By 
David Leonhardt
Good morning. We’re covering Trump’s slow tariff rollout — as well as immigration, abortion pills and podcasts.
President Trump after signing executive orders in the Oval Office. 
Doug Mills/The New York Times
Fast and slow
Donald Trump’s second presidency is obviously off to a fast start. In almost every area that’s a priority for him and his advisers — immigration, energy, climate, race, gender and more — he has begun making major policy changes.
But there is one notable exception: tariffs.
Even though Trump has said that “the most beautiful word in the dictionary is ‘tariff,’” he has been cautious in his first week back in office. He has not imposed the universal 10 percent or 20 percent charge on all imports that he promised during the campaign. He has instead threatened to enact targeted tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China that wouldn’t take effect until Feb. 1. Trump’s aides have signaled that the threat is partly a negotiating tool to win other concessions from those countries.
Trump has also directed government agencies to assess the feasibility of broader tariffs and report back on the findings, which is itself a sign of his caution. Feasibility assessments are not normally the modus operandi of Trumpism.
Wall Street, which tends to oppose tariffs, has noticed the caution. The S&P 500 
rose again yesterday,
 and market analysts said the slow movement on tariffs was one reason. “The worst fears have not been realized,” said David Kelly, chief global strategist at J.P. Morgan Asset Management.
Why is Trump proceeding more tentatively on tariffs? That’s the subject of today’s newsletter.
Internal worries
The New York Stock Exchange yesterday. 
Timothy A. Clary/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
Trump’s second administration is largely unified on most big issues, at least for now. His White House advisers and cabinet secretaries agree on the importance of expanding oil and gas production. They are dismissive of the risks and costs of climate change (despite the evidence). They oppose many diversity programs.
Any disagreements tend to be about secondary questions. On immigration, for example, Trump and his team favor much tougher border rules and an acceleration of deportations. The main area of internal disagreement involves a more niche subject: how many highly skilled immigrants to admit through the H-1B visa program.
On tariffs, the internal tensions run deeper. Nobody publicly opposes tariffs. But some senior officials were skeptical of tariffs before they entered Trump’s orbit. The corporate executives close to Trump are also wary, as is Wall Street.
The stock market is one of the few traditional restraints that matter to Trump, as 
my colleagues Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman have noted
. Trump sees stock prices as a report card on his presidency. And he knows that much of Wall Street worries that tariffs could hurt economic growth by raising prices in the U.S. and by sparking retaliatory tariffs elsewhere.
Some new tariffs are still likely because of Trump’s passion for them. Trade policy is a rare issue on which he has expressed consistent views for decades. (Immigration is another.) The uncertainty involves the form that the tariffs will take.
Three tariff goals
A steel plant in Huaian, China. 
Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
Ana Swanson, who covers trade for The Times, has a helpful way of framing the issue. She points out that during the confirmation hearing for Scott Bessent, the nominee for Treasury secretary, he encouraged people to think about the Trump tariffs as having three main goals:
1. Bring production home. 
Bessent said tariffs could play a role in “remedying unfair trade practices” by other countries and cited China as an example. If other countries are heavily subsidizing their own companies or keeping out foreign rivals, the U.S. can respond in kind to level the playing field.
The broader goal is to rework the supply chain, Ana notes. The U.S. can use tariffs to encourage more production in this country, especially in industries that are growing or militarily sensitive, by increasing the cost of foreign goods.
2. Raise revenue:
 Bessent’s second category was “a more generalized tariff as a revenue raiser.” Trump has proposed a huge tax cut, and tariffs could replace the lost revenue to keep the deficit from soaring. The Republican majorities in Congress are so narrow that a tax cut without offsetting deficit reduction may not be able to pass. House Republicans have 
floated cuts to Medicaid
 for the same reason.
3. Gain leverage:
 Bessent’s third category was leverage with other countries: “Tariffs can be used for negotiations,” he said. Trump this week threatened Russia with tariffs unless it agreed to a reasonable cease-fire in Ukraine. His planned tariffs on Canada and Mexico are partly an attempt to force concessions on border policy and a trade deal.
Speaking to political and business leaders in Davos yesterday, Trump vaguely threatened new tariffs on European countries. He has long criticized Europe for not buying more American products and not spending more on their militaries. They might be willing to make some changes if the alternative is economically damaging tariffs.
What’s next
The people in the administration who are wary of tariffs — you can think of them as the doves — seem to hope that this third category ends up being the dominant one. As Ana told me, “The dovish advisers want tariffs to be used as a negotiating tool that doesn’t actually go into effect, or even as a negotiating tool that could lead to more market opening.”
The hawks are more focused on the first two categories and the actual enactment of tariffs. Trump himself is enough of a hawk that at least some tariffs probably will go into effect.
Their scope may depend on what happens after that. If tariffs start to have the negative effects that their critics predict — higher inflation, lower profits and a trade war — Trump will likely pull back. If they seem to be working, or at least not failing, Trump may end up being a lot bolder than he has been in the past few days.
THE LATEST NEWS
Immigration
Outside the U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement building in Chicago. 
Vincent Alban/Reuters
The Trump administration is giving Immigration and Customs Enforcement officials the 
power to quickly deport migrants
 who were allowed into the United States temporarily under Biden-era programs.
A federal judge temporarily 
blocked Trump’s executive order
 to end birthright citizenship. He called the order “blatantly unconstitutional.”
Democrats are 
talking less about sanctuary cities,
 which many had once advertised with pride.
Trump’s Personnel
A procedural 
Senate vote to advance Pete Hegseth’s nomination
 for defense secretary passed, 51-49. Two Republicans — Susan Collins and Lisa Murkowski — voted against it.
The Trump administration 
revoked the security protection
 for Mike Pompeo, Trump’s former secretary of state.
John Ratcliffe 
was confirmed as C.I.A. director.
Kash Patel, Trump’s pick for F.B.I. chief, has 
embraced conspiracies
 — including the false theory that the agency he may soon lead helped instigate the Jan. 6 assault on the Capitol.
Abortion
Instagram and Facebook 
blocked and hid abortion pill providers’ posts
. The platforms suspended some accounts but later restored them.
A new study suggests a 
possible alternative to the abortion pill
. It includes the key ingredient in the morning-after pill.
More on Politics
In 1963, minutes before John F. Kennedy was assassinated. 
Bettmann Archive, via Getty Images
Trump signed an order to 
declassify and release
 documents related to the assassinations of John F. Kennedy, Robert F. Kennedy and Martin Luther King Jr.
Trump is leading a 
global surge to the right
. Populists in Europe are watching him closely.
Before the election, Trump assured Libertarian voters that he would free Ross Ulbricht, the imprisoned creator of an online drug marketplace. This week, 
he did just that
.
Video shows how Jan. 6 rioters who were pardoned by Trump attacked the police. 
Watch the footage here
.
International
The teenager who killed three young girls in a knife attack on a dance class in England was 
sentenced to life in prison
.
Russia has suffered twice as many deaths and injuries as Ukraine in the war, according to experts and journalists working to count the dead. But Russia is 
still winning
.
Trump restored the designation of Yemen’s Houthi rebels, who have fired on ships in the Red Sea in solidarity with Hamas, 
as a “foreign terrorist organization.”
 The Biden administration had weakened the designation.
Business
OpenAI introduced a new tool, called Operator, that can 
autonomously perform tasks on the internet
, like buying groceries and booking restaurant reservations.
CNN is cutting 200 jobs in its TV division as the company 
shifts its focus toward digital audiences
.
Police officers 
freed the founder of a French cryptocurrency company
, Ledger, and his wife after they were kidnapped and held for ransom.
Other Big Stories
Near Castaic, Calif. 
Mark Abramson for The New York Times
A wildfire burning northwest of Los Angeles has 
kept thousands of people away from their homes
.
People with A.D.H.D. 
are dying earlier
 than those without the disorder, according to a study.
A major storm, with wind speeds of a Category 3 hurricane, is hitting Ireland and Britain. 
A third of Ireland is without power
.
Opinions
After the devastating 1871 fire, Chicago 
rebuilt with stronger fire protections
. Los Angeles should learn from its example, 
Carl Smith
 writes.
Why don’t we have a cure for Alzheimer’s? Because 
fraud and misconduct have hampered research
, writes 
Charles Piller
, an investigative science journalist.
Here are columns by 
David Brooks
 on 
19th-century America
 and 
Michelle Goldberg
 on 
a crackdown on the academic left
.
Receive free access to handpicked articles via text message.
Now you can get Times journalism sent right to your phone. Each article will be accessible for 30 days.
Sign up now
MORNING READS
Javier Jaén
Blood filter:
 A start-up claimed its device could cure cancer. 
Then patients began dying
.
Sleep:
 
Read these six common misconceptions about sleep
 — and learn how to actually get a better rest.
“Humanity’s Last Exam”:
 Researchers have created a 
3,000-question quiz
 to test A.I. systems.
The Ethicist: 
On the difference between 
noticing attractive women and ogling them
.
Quite a find: 
In Greece, a man discovered 
an ancient statue in the trash
.
Can’t afford a new house? 
Build one in the backyard
.
Lives Lived:
 Charles Phan was a self-taught chef whose family fled Vietnam when he was a teenager and whose sleek restaurant helped change America’s perception of Asian food. 
He died at 62
.
SPORTS
Tennis: 
Novak Djokovic exited 
after just one set of his Australian Open semifinal match
 against Alexander Zverev. Djokovic had suffered a leg injury in his quarterfinal win.
M.L.B.:
 The Athletic obtained audio of Ippei Mizuhara, the former translator for Dodgers superstar Shohei Ohtani, impersonating the baseball player while requesting a $200,000 wire transfer. 
Listen to it here
.
N.F.L.: 
Buccaneers offensive coordinator Liam Coen is 
expected to accept
 the Jaguars head-coaching job — just hours after the franchise parted ways with its general manager.
ARTS AND IDEAS
Jason Kelce at a taping for his new show. 
Hannah Yoon for The New York Times
The former N.F.L. player Jason Kelce has been busy since retiring. He has built a career as an analyst and podcaster and appeared in commercials for Campbell’s soup, Marriott hotels, General Mills foods, YouTube TV, Buffalo Wild Wings and Tide. This month he will begin yet another job: 
ESPN late-night host
.
More on culture
Zoe Saldaña in a scene from “Emilia Pérez.” 
Page 114 – Why Not Productions – Pathé Films – France 2 Cinéma/Netflix, via Associated Press
The Oscar nominations were announced. “Emilia Perez,” “The Brutalist” “ and “Wicked” were nominated in many categories. 
See the list
.
Jimmy Kimmel mocked Trump 
before the president’s visit to Los Angeles
.
THE MORNING RECOMMENDS …
Ryan Liebe for The New York Times
Layer
 
smashed beef kebab
 over cucumber yogurt.
Tell 
us 
about the one who got away
.
Organize 
your closet
.
Take
 
our news quiz
.
GAMES
Here is 
today’s Spelling Bee
. Yesterday’s pangram was 
bookmobile
.
And here are 
today’s Mini Crossword
, 
Wordle
, 
Sudoku
, 
Connections
 and 
Strands
.
Thanks for spending part of your morning with The Times. See you tomorrow.

. Reach our team at 
themorning@nytimes.com

subject: Call for speakers - HR, talent, benefits and more
body:
Happy New Year! We’re thrilled to share our 2025 event lineup, featuring 20+ single-day live conferences in cities across the U.S. and 12 virtual events designed to bring together HR / Talent / Benefits executives and decision-makers.
Our invitation-only events will showcase panels, keynotes, breakout workshops, and exclusive networking sessions. Topics will include employee engagement, effective employee benefits, modernizing talent acquisition, fostering inclusive workplaces, skills development, and more.
We’re excited to host distinguished speakers, such as:
SVP and Culture Officer - The Home Depot
Chief Leadership, Culture and Inclusion Officer - IBM
Chief Human Resources Officer - Baker Hughes
Chief Human Resources Officer - Rakuten
Executive Vice President of Human Resources - Gilead
Chief Human Resources Officer - Fortive
Vice President, Talent Engagement and Experience - Comcast
Global SVP, Learning & Organizational Development, HR - Epsilon
Director, Global Benefits - BuzzFeed
We’d love for you to be part of the conversation as a sponsor in 2025! If you're interested in booking a meeting to 
explore speaking sponsorship or exhibitor opportunities or learning more about joining us at one of these events, simply reply to this email and I'd be happy to connect you with someone from our team.
Looking forward to connecting!
Best,
Erin Sauter, CoFounder, From Day One
Confirmed single-day conferences for 2025 include: 
Atlanta – January 28
Washington, D.C. – February 4
Houston – February 11
Salt Lake City – February 25
Silicon Valley – March 6
Seattle – March 25
Dallas – April 16
Minneapolis – May 13
Chicago – June 5
Manhattan – June 10
Austin – September 24
San Francisco – September 30
Philadelphia – October 7
Boston – October 21
Los Angeles – December 3
Half-Day Benefits Conferences: For Benefits Executives Only
Boston - April 2
Manhattan - April 24
Half-Day Talent Acquisition Conferences: For Talent Executives Only
Manhattan - April 23 
 
2025 VIRTUAL CONFERENCES
January 22 - Benefits & Total Rewards
Innovation in Total Rewards: How Creative Leaders Are Finding Affordable Solutions
 
February 19 - Talent Acquisition
Making Talent Acquisition a Strategic Part of Workforce Planning and Growth
 
March 12 - Employee Engagement
Putting Employee Experience at the Center of HR Leadership
 
April 23 - Wellness & Family Benefits
Better Benefits: Supporting the Health and Well-Being of Workers and Their Families
 
May 21 - Employee Recognition
The Role of HR Leaders in Building a Culture of Recognition and Feedback
 
June 11 - Inclusion & Belonging
Charting the Future of Diversity, Equity, Inclusion and Belonging
 
July 16 - Benefits
Navigating the New Landscape of Employee-Benefit Solutions
 
August 13 - Learning, Development, and Skills
Leading the Charge on Skills-Based Learning and Development
 
September 10 - Productivity & Efficiency Tools
Productivity Boosters: How HR Leaders Can Play a Significant Role in Worker Efficiency
 
October 15 - Managing a Global Workforce
Building and Managing a Global Workforce: Smart Strategies for Collaborating Across Borders
 
November 12 - HR Technology
The Empowering Effect of HR Tech: Deciding Where It Will Make a Difference
 
December 10 - Future of Work
What’s Around the Corner: Workers and Workplaces in 2026 and Beyond

Absolutely! Thank you Sarah, Rebecca and Juri! I will let Brian and Lukeisha know of this agreement and to expect the date and time update.
 
Kind regards,
Shelton

Please decline today’s meeting and I’ll send you a new invitation for next week right away. 
 
Cheers!
Rebecca

Hi Juri,

th

Kindest regards,

Hi Juri,
 
Thank you for confirming. Unfortunately, for the sake of securing a slot I think we should opt to transition to another date and time. I was trying to get us to meet sooner as this is a top priority.
 
Could we proceed with the 3-4pm on 1/23?
 
Kind regards,
Shelton

Hi Juri,
 
I hope you are well. 
 
Thank you for sending this along. I see you were up early.
 
Quick share:
We may have to shift this time around. I will keep you posted as Brian may not be able to attend until at 11am and Lukeisha has an 11am meeting. I am looking to see if her 11am meeting is adjustable. If so, we may need to shift to an 11am – 12pm meeting.
 
Kind regards,
Shelton

Hi Juri,
 
Hope this email finds you well. 
 
I was informed today that you and I are to connect to establish another meeting time for next week. Here’s what I have for Lukeisha and Brian’s availability does any of the below times work for you all?
 
Jan 21 10:30-12 
Jan 23 3-4:30 
Jan 24 11-2
 
Agenda:
Discuss 1/24 make-up session
Discuss timeline approach and readiness
Space for open discussion
 
Kind regards,
 
Shelton Rankin

336-279-0217

th
 Floor
175 Greenwich Street
New York, NY 10007

www.groupm.com
@groupmworldwide
Follow us on LinkedIn

A safe space. A listening ear. A trusted ally.
BLACK LIVES MATTER.
